newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU farm aid for E.Europe needs review - report.
newsitem.headline: EU farm aid for E.Europe needs review - report.

text.p: Compensatory payments to farmers will have to be redefined after central and eastern European countries join the European Union, the European Commission's economics directorate said on Wednesday.
"Would it be possible to defend a policy which transfers important cash subsidies to farmers in the rich EU countries, but not to farmers in the poorer CEECs ?" the report said.
EU farmers are currently compensated for cuts in intervention prices made under 1992 farm reforms and for income losses caused by compulsory set-aside of arable land.
But the report on "The Common Agricultural Policy and Enlargement," said there were several reasons why the payments should not be extended to 10 prospective CEEC new members.
It reiterated ideas put forward in a European Commission eastern Europe farm strategy paper presented to the EU summit in Madrid last December.
It said eastern European countries would not suffer income losses because they would benefit from higher EU farm prices.
Compensatory payments would increase the value of farm land and may hamper structural development of farms and rural development.
Farmers were also likely to gain greater benefit than workers in other sectors because of higher EU farm prices.
The payments may benefit landowners, who in the Czech republic and other countries are mainly urban dwellers, the report added.
Eastern European farms are often big industrial units and completely different from EU family farms.
Structural measures may be a better method to aid farmers in eastern Europe, the report suggested.
